statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description:
Steve Smith loves to look inside and see
teams trying to stop Tim Duncan and David Robinson.
article.headline: With the hot hand outside, Smith hits for 29 points
article.linkText: Smith takes control as Spurs put away Jazz
article.story:
SALT LAKE CITY (AP) -- Steve Smith loves to look inside and see teams trying to stop Tim Duncan and David Robinson. Sooner or later, he knows the ball is coming his way. Smith went 5-for-5 from 3-point range and scored 29 points -- including 18 in the second quarter -- to lead the sharp-shooting San Antonio Spurs past the Utah Jazz 98-92 Wednesday night. "Some nights we have it, some nights we're off," Smith said. "We all moved the ball a little better tonight than in these last few games. When we move the ball and share it, drive and kick, we're a tough team to defend." Tim Duncan had 26 points to give San Antonio its eighth consecutive victory against the Jazz. Utah pulled to 90-88 with two minutes to play on a jumper by Karl Malone, but Smith, Duncan and Terry Porter each hit free throws in the final 28.2 seconds to preserve the victory. "We've had 10 of 11 of these games this year, and it doesn't mean nothing to me to come close," Malone said. "You get no consolation for coming close, just like the NBA Finals." The Spurs went 10-for-10 from the line in the fourth quarter and 28-for-29 overall. They also finished 10-for-18 from 3-point range (55 percent) and 30-for-57 from the floor (52 percent) to win despite failing to grab a single offensive rebound. "We were great at the free-throw line and we were great from the perimeter," San Antonio coach Gregg Popovich said. "That's a great combination when you've got Duncan down low doing his thing." Smith, who leads the NBA with a 53 percent average from 3-point range, hit four of his 3-point attempts in the second period. "It felt good. I made some open shots. Guys set some good picks," he said. Malone had 23 points and 10 rebounds to lead Utah while John Amaechi scored a season-high 18, scoring 16 in the second half and making his first baskets since a double-overtime defeat against Memphis on Jan. 12. "It's never great when you play well in a loss," said Amaechi, who signed as a free agent last summer. "Your first good game, essentially, is a loss. But it's reassuring, perhaps, to the people who pay the bills." John Stockton added 10 points and 11 assists while Andre Kirilenko scored 16. Smith was unstoppable in the second quarter. He connected on a 3-point prayer to beat the shot clock midway through the period and faked Kirilenko to add another at the halftime buzzer, giving the Spurs a 51-45 lead. "We've been struggling a little with our shots from the outside but we got some clean ones off," Duncan said. "Smitty got us started early, with some not-so-clean looks, but he still knocked them out." The Spurs rebounded from consecutive defeats to two of the league's best teams, the Los Angeles Lakers and New Jersey Nets. "We came off a couple of disappointing games," said Robinson, who scored 10. "We needed to take care of the details, the smaller things. We did a better job of that. Defensively, we did a nice job." The Jazz trailed 80-66 going into the fourth quarter but opened the period with an 11-2 run. Stockton found Amaechi for a layup from the left side, cutting the margin to 92-90 with 47 seconds remaining, but Utah was forced to foul and couldn't score again until Malone put back two misses by Bryon Russell with 7.1 seconds to go. Game notes
NBC Sports chairman Dick Ebersol and broadcaster Bob Costas sat in the front row next to Jazz owner Larry Miller and his wife, Gail. NBC crews are in town preparing for the 2002 Winter Olympics. ... Jazz forward Donyell Marshall went on the injured list Wednesday with a bruised right hip. After sitting out five games, he played eight minutes Monday at Golden State before reinjuring himself. ... Duncan had eight points in the first half against Utah center Jarron Collins and threw down a roundhouse dunk on the rookie after the break. ... Russell shot 1-for-8. He is 15-for-53 in his last six games. ... The Jazz haven't beaten San Antonio since Feb. 6, 2000.
